It could - assuming that their are no cracks in the integration testing. Un=
it testing is far easier to cover fully because each section is smaller. In=
tegration testing involves a large number of things working together. There=
fore, you know the integration testing failed - but no where it failed. Whe=
n a unit test fails you have a far smaller haystack to search.

However, if=
 I have done a proper job of unit testing against a published specification=
 then my confidence level entering integration testing is far higher than s=
omeone that did no unit testing. Therefore, on a integration testing failur=
e it should not be in my code.


Chip

 Unit testing gives you confidence in your objects. Integration

between your obj=
ects and confidence in your objects?
